static NaviManager & Get ()

Detailed Description

Supreme dictator and Singleton: NaviManager

The class you will need to go to for all your Navi-related needs.

Member Function Documentation

NaviManager & NaviManager::Get (  )  [static]

Gets the NaviManager Singleton, this is the only way to access NaviManager.

Returns:
A reference to the NaviManager Singleton.

void NaviManager::Startup ( Ogre::RenderWindow *  _renderWindow,
const std::string &  _localNaviDirectory = "NaviLocal" 
)

Starts up the NaviManager and internal LLMozLib library.

Parameters:
_renderWindow The Ogre::RenderWindow to render Navis to
_localNaviDirectory By default, "local://" means something like: "C:\MyApplicationDirectory\NaviLocal\" but by changing this parameter, you can change "NaviLocal" to something else.
Exceptions:
Ogre::Exception::ERR_INTERNAL_ERROR Throws this when LLMozLib fails initialization

NaviMouse * NaviManager::StartupMouse ( bool  visible = true  ) 

Starts up the NaviMouse singleton and returns a pointer to it.

Parameters:
visible Whether or not the NaviMouse is visible. Use NaviMouse::show()/hide() later.

NaviMouse * NaviManager::getMouse (  ) 

Returns the NaviMouse singleton.

Exceptions:
Ogre::Exception::ERR_RT_ASSERTION_FAILED Throws this if StartupMouse() is not called prior.

void NaviManager::Update (  ) 

Gives each active Navi a chance to update, each may or may not update their internal textures based on various conditions.

void NaviManager::Shutdown (  ) 

Destroys any active Navis and shuts down the LLMozLib library.

void NaviManager::createNavi ( const std::string &  naviName,
const std::string &  homepage,
const NaviPosition &  naviPosition,
unsigned short  width,
unsigned short  height,
bool  isMovable = true,
bool  isVisible = true,
unsigned int  maxUpdatesPerSec = 48,
bool  forceMaxUpdate = false,
unsigned short  zOrder = 0,
float  opacity = 1.0 
)

Creates a Navi. (You MUST call Startup() before this.)

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi, used to refer to a specific Navi in subsequent calls.
homepage The default starting page for a Navi. You may use local:// here to refer to the local Navi directory (See NaviManager::Startup)
naviPosition The unified position (either relative or absolute) of a Navi. See NaviManager::NaviPosition for more information.
width The width of the Navi. MUST be a power of 2 (e.g. 128, 256, 512, 1024) Technically you may be able to use a number that is divisible by 16 but please be mindful of the 2^n texture size limitation of certain video cards
height The height of the Navi. MUST be a power of 2 (e.g. 128, 256, 512, 1024) Technically you may be able to use a number that is divisible by 16 but please be mindful of the 2^n texture size limitation of certain video cards
isMovable Whether or not this absolutely positioned Navi is movable (right-click-drag to move)
isVisible Whether or not this Navi is visible upon creation. Use NaviManager::showNavi to display this Navi later.
maxUpdatesPerSec This parameter limits the number of updates per second to a specific integer. To use no limiting, leave this parameter as '0'. This limiting is useful if, for example, you had some very hyperactive Javascript that animated a moving ball. Without update limiting, Navi will try to update itself at every possible moment: this is great for very smooth animation but bad for the overall framerate.
forceMaxUpdate Navi normally only updates when the page has changed, to override this functionality set this parameter to 'True' to make Navi 'force update' using the value of the parameter 'maxUpdatesPerSec'. This is useful as a work-around for rendering embedded Flash applications. Note: if 'maxUpdatesPerSec' is 0, Navi will try to 'force update' every single chance it gets (not recommended).
zOrder Sets the starting Z-Order for this Navi; Navis with higher Z-Orders will be on top of other Navis. To auto-increment this value for every successive Navi, leave this parameter as '0'.
opacity Sets the starting Opacity of the Navi. Ex. 1.0000 = Fully opaque Ex. 0.5000 = Half opaque Ex. 0.0000 = Totally transparent
Exceptions:
Ogre::Exception::ERR_RT_ASSERTION_FAILED Throws this if NaviManager::Startup is not called prior to this.

std::string NaviManager::createNaviMaterial ( const std::string &  naviName,
const std::string &  homepage,
unsigned short  width,
unsigned short  height,
bool  isVisible = true,
unsigned int  maxUpdatesPerSec = 48,
bool  forceMaxUpdate = false,
float  opacity = 1.0,
Ogre::FilterOptions  texFiltering = Ogre::FO_ANISOTROPIC 
)

Creates a NaviMaterial. (You MUST call Startup() before this.) NaviMaterials are just like Navis except that they lack a movable overlay element. Instead, you handle the material and apply it to anything you like. Mouse input for NaviMaterials must be injected using the 'injectNaviMaterial...(...)' API calls.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the NaviMaterial, used to refer to this specific Navi in subsequent calls.
homepage The default starting page for a Navi. You may use local:// here to refer to the local Navi directory (See NaviManager::Startup)
width The width of the NaviMaterial. MUST be a power of 2 (e.g. 128, 256, 512, 1024) Technically you may be able to use a number that is divisible by 16 but please be mindful of the 2^n texture size limitation of certain video cards
height The height of the NaviMaterial. MUST be a power of 2 (e.g. 128, 256, 512, 1024) Technically you may be able to use a number that is divisible by 16 but please be mindful of the 2^n texture size limitation of certain video cards
isVisible Whether or not this NaviMaterial is visible or not (0% opacity, non-updated). Use NaviManager::showNavi to display this NaviMaterial later.
maxUpdatesPerSec This parameter limits the number of updates per second to a specific integer. To use no limiting, leave this parameter as '0'. This limiting is useful if, for example, you had some very hyperactive Javascript that animated a moving ball. Without update limiting, Navi will try to update itself at every possible moment: this is great for very smooth animation but bad for the overall framerate.
forceMaxUpdate Navi normally only updates when the page has changed, to override this functionality set this parameter to 'True' to make Navi 'force update' using the value of the parameter 'maxUpdatesPerSec'. This is useful as a work-around for rendering embedded Flash applications. Note: if 'maxUpdatesPerSec' is 0, Navi will try to 'force update' every single chance it gets (not recommended).
opacity Sets the starting Opacity of the Navi. Ex. 1.0000 = Fully opaque Ex. 0.5000 = Half opaque Ex. 0.0000 = Totally transparent
texFiltering The texture filtering to use for this material. If the NaviMaterial is applied to a 3D object, anisotropic is the best choice, otherwise set this to none for use in other overlays/GUI elements.
Exceptions:
Ogre::Exception::ERR_RT_ASSERTION_FAILED Throws this if NaviManager::Startup is not called prior to this.

void NaviManager::navigateNaviTo ( const std::string &  naviName,
const std::string &  url 
)

Changes the page of the Navi to a supplied URL String.

naviData The NaviData to send.

std::string NaviManager::naviEvaluateJS ( const std::string &  naviName,
const std::string &  script 
)

Evaluates a Javascript string in the context of a Navi page and returns the result.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
script The Javascript (as a string) to evaluate/execute in the context of the page that the Navi is currently on.
Returns:
If it succeeds, this will return the result as a string (regardless of internal Javascript datatype), otherwise this returns an empty string.

void NaviManager::setNaviBackgroundColor ( const std::string &  naviName,
float  red = 1.0f,
float  green = 1.0f,
float  blue = 1.0f 
)

Sets the default color to use between changing pages, the default is White if you never call this.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
red The Red color value as a float; maximum 1.0, minimum 0.0.
green The Green color value as a float; maximum 1.0, minimum 0.0.
blue The Blue color value as a float; maximum 1.0, minimum 0.0.

void NaviManager::setNaviBackgroundColor ( const std::string &  naviName,
const std::string &  hexColor = "#FFFFFF" 
)

Sets the default color to use between changing pages, the default is White ("#FFFFFF") if you never call this.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
hexColor A hex color string in the format of: "#XXXXXX"

void NaviManager::setNaviOpacity ( const std::string &  naviName,
float  opacity = 1.0f 
)

Changes the Opacity of a Navi to a provided float.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
opacity The Opacity value as a float. Fully Opaque = 1.0, Fully Transparent = 0.0.

void NaviManager::setNaviMask ( const std::string &  naviName,
const std::string &  maskFileName,
const std::string &  groupName = Ogre::ResourceGroupManager::DEFAULT_RESOURCE_GROUP_NAME 
)

Sets the filename of the Alpha Mask Image. Navi will use the alpha channel values of the provided image to mask a Navi dynamically.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
maskFileName The filename of the Alpha Mask Image. The Alpha Mask Image MUST have a width greater than or equal to the Navi width and it MUST have a height greater than or equal to the Navi height. Alpha Mask Images larger than the Navi will not be stretched, instead Navi will take Alpha values starting from the Top-Left corner of the Alpha Mask Image. To reset Navi to use no Alpha Mask Image, simply provide an empty String ("").
groupName The Resource Group to find the Alpha Mask Image filename.
Exceptions:
Ogre::Exception::ERR_INVALIDPARAMS Throws this if the width or height of the Alpha Mask Image is less than the width or height of the Navi it is applied to.

void NaviManager::setNaviIgnoreTransparent ( const std::string &  naviName,
bool  ignoreTrans = true,
float  defineThreshold = 0.05 
)

Using an alpha-mask/color-keying doesn't just affect the visuals of a Navi; by default, Navis 'ignore' mouse movement/clicks over 'transparent' areas of a Navi (Areas with opacity less than 5%). You may disable this behavior or redefine the 'transparent' threshold of opacity to something else other than 5%.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
ignoreTrans Whether or not Navis should ignore 'transparent' areas when mouse-picking.
defineThreshold Areas with opacity less than this percent will be ignored. Default is 5%.

void NaviManager::setNaviIgnoreBounds ( const std::string &  naviName,
bool  ignoreBounds = true 
)

Normally, mouse movement is only injected into a specific Navi if the mouse is within the boundaries of a Navi and over an opaque area (not transparent). This behavior may be detrimental to certain Navis, for example an animated 'dock' with floating icons on a transparent background: the mouse-out event would never be invoked on each icon because the Navi only received mouse movement input over opaque areas. Use this function to tell a Navi to always inject mouse movement, regardless of boundaries or transparency.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
ignoreBounds Whether or not this Navi should ignore bounds/transparency when injecting mouse movement.
Note:
The occlusivity of each Navi will still be respected, mouse movement will not be injected if another Navi is occluding the Navi you set this on.

void NaviManager::setNaviColorKey ( const std::string &  naviName,
const std::string &  keyColor,
float  keyFillOpacity = 0.0,
const std::string &  keyFillColor = "#000000",
float  keyFuzziness = 0.0 
)

Using an alpha-mask isn't the only way to achieve transparency of a Navi, you can use color-keying instead or at the same time with alpha-masking to achieve the desired result. Color-keying effectively replaces a certain color on the Navi page with a custom color/opacity.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
keyColor The color to replace, as a Hex RGB String (Must be "#XXXXXX" !!). Pass an empty string to disable color-keying.
keyFillOpacity The opacity of the fill color to replace the key color with, as a percent.
keyFillColor The fill color to replace the key color with, as a Hex RGB String (Must be "#XXXXXX" !!)
keyFuzziness The amount of 'fuzziness' to use when keying out a color. Increase this to additionally key out colors that are similar to the key color. The relative opacity of each 'fuzzy' color will also be calculated based on the color distance to the key color. There is some slight overhead when using a keyFuzziness other than 0.0, it's best to use this with Navis that don't update too often.

void NaviManager::setMaxUpdatesPerSec ( const std::string &  naviName,
unsigned int  maxUPS = 0 
)

Limits the number of times per second a Navi may update.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
maxUPS The maximum number of times per second a Navi can update. Set this to '0' to use no update limiting. If the current Navi is set to 'Force Max Updates', this value is used as the number of updates per second to actually do.

void NaviManager::setForceMaxUpdate ( const std::string &  naviName,
bool  forceMaxUpdate = false 
)

Toggles between auto-updating and force-updating.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
forceMaxUpdate Navi normally only updates when the page has changed, to override this functionality set this parameter to 'True' to make Navi 'force update' using the value of the parameter 'maxUpdatesPerSec'. This is useful as a work-around for rendering embedded Flash applications. Note: if 'maxUpdatesPerSec' is 0, Navi will try to 'force update' every single chance it gets (not recommended). Set this to 'False' to make Navi update only when the page changes (auto-updating).

void NaviManager::moveNavi ( const std::string &  naviName,
int  deltaX,
int  deltaY 
)

Moves a movable non-material Navi by relative amounts.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
deltaX The relative X amount to move the Navi by. Positive amounts move it right.
deltaY The relative Y amount to move the Navi by. Positive amounts move it down.

void NaviManager::setNaviPosition ( const std::string &  naviName,
const NaviPosition &  naviPosition 
)

Sets the default position of a non-material Navi to a new position and subsequently moves the Navi to this position. This will work on non-movable non-material Navis.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
naviPosition The new NaviPosition to set the Navi to.

void NaviManager::resetAllPositions (  ) 

Resets the positions of all movable Navis to the positions they were created with.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
fade Whether or not to fade the Navi up.
fadeDurationMS If fading, the number of milliseconds to fade for.

std::string NaviManager::getNaviMaterialName ( const std::string &  naviName  ) 

Gets the name of the Ogre Material that is used internally for a certain Navi.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi that you wish to find the Material name of.
Returns:
If the Navi is found, returns the name of the internal Ogre Material, otherwise an empty string is returned.

Ogre::PanelOverlayElement * NaviManager::getNaviInternalPanel ( const std::string &  naviName  ) 

Gets a pointer to the Ogre::OverlayContainer (Panel) that is used internally for a certain Navi. Please remember that NaviMaterials have no Panel and thus, this function only works with full Navis.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi that you wish to retrieve the Panel of
Returns:
If the Navi is found and it is NOT a NaviMaterial, returns a pointer to the Panel, otherwise 0 is returned.

bool NaviManager::getNaviVisibility ( const std::string &  naviName  ) 

Gets the current visibility of the Navi.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to get the visibility of.
Returns:
Whether or not the Navi is visible. Additionally returns false if the Navi is not found.

void NaviManager::getDerivedUV ( const std::string &  naviName,
Ogre::Real &  u1,
Ogre::Real &  v1,
Ogre::Real &  u2,
Ogre::Real &  v2 
)

Gets the derived UV's of the Navi's internal material/texture. On certain systems we must compensate for lack of NPOT on the videocard by using the next-highest POT texture. Normal Navi's compensate their UV's accordingly however NaviMaterials will need to adjust their own by use of this function.

bool NaviManager::injectMouseMove ( int  xPos,
int  yPos 
)

Injects absolute mouse coordinates into NaviManager. Used to generally keep track of where the mouse is for things like moving Navis around, telling the internal pages of each Navi where the mouse is and where the user has clicked, etc.

Parameters:
xPos The absolute X-Value of the mouse.
yPos The absolute Y-Value of the mouse.
Returns:
Returns True if the injected coordinate is over a Navi, False otherwise.

void NaviManager::injectNaviMouseMove ( const std::string &  naviName,
int  xPos,
int  yPos 
)

Injects absolute mouse coordinates (in the Navi's own local coordinate space) into a specific Navi/NaviMaterial.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi/NaviMaterial to inject this into.
xPos The absolute X-Value of the mouse, relative to the Navi/NaviMaterial's origin.
yPos The absolute Y-Value of the mouse, relative to the Navi/NaviMaterial's origin.

bool NaviManager::injectMouseWheel ( int  relScroll  ) 

Injects mouse wheel events into NaviManager. Used to scroll the focused Navi.

Parameters:
relScroll The relative Scroll-Value of the mouse.
Note:
To inject this using OIS: on a OIS::MouseListener::MouseMoved event, simply inject "arg.state.Z.rel" of the "MouseEvent".
Returns:
Returns True if the mouse wheel was scrolled while a Navi was focused, False otherwise.

void NaviManager::injectNaviMouseWheel ( const std::string &  naviName,
int  relScroll 
)

Injects mouse wheel events into a specific Navi/NaviMaterial.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi/NaviMaterial to inject this into.
relScroll The relative Scroll-Value of the mouse.
Note:
To inject this using OIS: on a OIS::MouseListener::MouseMoved event, simply inject "arg.state.Z.rel" of the "MouseEvent".

bool NaviManager::injectMouseDown ( int  buttonID  ) 

Injects mouse down events into NaviManager. Used to know when the user has pressed a mouse button and which button they used.

Parameters:
buttonID The ID of the button that was pressed. Left = 0, Right = 1, Middle = 2.
Returns:
Returns True if the mouse went down over a Navi, False otherwise.

void NaviManager::injectNaviMouseDown ( const std::string &  naviName,
int  buttonID,
int  xPos,
int  yPos 
)

Injects mouse down events into a specific Navi/NaviMaterial.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi/NaviMaterial to inject this into.
buttonID The ID of the button that was pressed. Left = 0, Right = 1, Middle = 2.
xPos The absolute X-Value of the mouse, relative to the Navi/NaviMaterial's origin.
yPos The absolute Y-Value of the mouse, relative to the Navi/NaviMaterial's origin.

bool NaviManager::injectMouseUp ( int  buttonID  ) 

Injects mouse up events into NaviManager. Used to know when the user has released a mouse button and which button they used.

Parameters:
buttonID The ID of the button that was released. Left = 0, Right = 1, Middle = 2.
Returns:
Returns True if the mouse went up while a Navi was focused, False otherwise.

yPos The absolute Y-Value of the mouse, relative to the Navi/NaviMaterial's origin.

void NaviManager::addNaviEventListener ( const std::string &  naviName,
NaviEventListener *  newListener 
)

Subscribes a NaviEventListener to listen for events from a certain Navi.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
newListener The address of the NaviEventListener. If you try to add the same NaviEventListener twice, subsequent attempts will be ignored.

void NaviManager::removeNaviEventListener ( const std::string &  naviName,
NaviEventListener *  removeListener 
)

Un-subscribes a NaviEventListener from a certain Navi.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to do this to.
removeListener The address of the NaviEventListener to remove.

void NaviManager::bind ( const std::string &  naviName,
const std::string &  naviDataName,
const NaviDelegate &  callback,
const std::vector< std::string > &  keys = std::vector<std::string>() 
)

Binds the reception of a NaviData object from a certain Navi to a delegate function (callback).

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to receive the NaviData object from.
naviDataName The name of the NaviData to bind the callback to.
callback The NaviDelegate to bind to. NaviDelegates must return a 'void' and have one argument: 'const NaviData &naviData' 
        // Member function instantiation:
        NaviDelegate(this, &MyClass::myMemberFunction)

        // Static function instantiation:
        NaviDelegate(&myStaticFunction)
keys An optional string vector containing the keys to ensure. See NaviData::ensure (second overload).
Note:
It is highly advised to use the NaviUtilities::Strings typedef to invoke this parameter.
An example: 
        naviMgr.bind("chat", "messageSent", NaviDelegate(this, &NaviDemo::messageSent), Strings("nick")("message"));

void NaviManager::unbind ( const std::string &  naviName,
const std::string &  naviDataName,
const NaviDelegate &  callback = NaviDelegate() 
)

Un-binds the reception of a NaviData object from a certain Navi to a delegate function (callback)

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to unbind the NaviData from.
naviDataName The name of the NaviData to unbind.
callback The specific NaviDelegate to unbind. This is optional, if it is left blank, all bindings to 'naviDataName' of 'naviName' will be released.

void NaviManager::focusNavi ( const std::string &  naviName  ) 

Focuses a Navi and pops it to the front of all other Navis.

Parameters:
naviName The name of the Navi to focus.

void NaviManager::deFocusAllNavis (  ) 

De-Focuses any currently-focused Navis. This would be useful if you need to disable any auto-key-injection (and subsequent display in a focused textbox of a focused Navi) done internally by Gecko.
